verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Direct introduction formula; consistent with previous sections.

verses.text: Tell Aaron and his sons to be careful with the holy offerings that the people of Israel dedicate to Me, so they do not profane My holy name by what they dedicate to Me. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: Maintains the sense of the Hebrew, using 'profane' modern equivalent.

verses.text: Say to them: If any of your descendants throughout your generations approaches the holy offerings that the people of Israel dedicate to the Lord while he is unclean, that person shall be cut off from My presence. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: "Cut off" follows the literal rendering, indicating exclusion or judgment.

verses.text: None of Aaron’s descendants who has leprosy or a discharge may eat of the holy offerings until he is clean. If anyone touches anything made unclean by a corpse or has an emission of semen,
verses.comment: Translates 'leprosy' for 'tzaraath', understood as a defiling skin disease.

verses.text: or touches any creeping thing that makes him unclean, or touches any person who makes him unclean, whatever his uncleanness may be—
verses.comment: Reference to ritual impurity, as defined in previous chapters.

verses.text: the person who touches any such thing shall be unclean until the evening and must not eat of the holy offerings unless he has washed his body with water.
verses.comment: "Washed his body"—literal rendering; "evening" marks the end of ritual impurity.

verses.text: When the sun sets, he shall be clean, and afterward he may eat of the holy offerings, because that is his food.
verses.comment: Follows literal chronology; 'his food' as a priestly right.

verses.text: He shall not eat what dies of itself or is torn by beasts and become unclean by it. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: Renders Hebrew 'nevelah' and 'terefah' idiomatically in modern English.

verses.text: They shall therefore keep My charge, so that they do not bear sin for it and die because they profane it. I am the Lord who sanctifies them.
verses.comment: Phrase 'bear sin' is retained as a biblical expression.

verses.text: No outsider shall eat the holy offerings. A guest of a priest or a hired worker shall not eat of the holy things.
verses.comment: Clarifies that only qualified priests/family may eat the offerings.

verses.text: But if a priest buys a slave as his property, that person may eat of it, and those born in his house may eat of his food.
verses.comment: 'Slave' is rendered literally; the social context is ancient Israel.

verses.text: If a priest’s daughter marries an outsider, she shall not eat of the holy contribution offerings.
verses.comment: Literal translation, 'outsider' refers to non-priest/lay Israelite.

verses.text: But if a priest’s daughter is widowed or divorced and has no child and returns to her father’s house as in her youth, she may eat of her father’s food; but no outsider may eat of it.
verses.comment: Literal; gives the conditions of eligibility for eating holy food.

verses.text: If anyone eats of a holy thing unintentionally, he shall add the fifth of its value to it and give the holy thing to the priest.
verses.comment: Includes the restitution law for accidental consumption.

verses.text: They shall not profane the holy offerings of the people of Israel, which they contribute to the Lord.
verses.comment: Follows the Hebrew, maintaining distinction between 'profane' and 'holy'.

verses.text: and so cause them to bear guilt by eating their holy offerings, for I am the Lord who sanctifies them.
verses.comment: Maintains original construction of bearing guilt.

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Marks transition to rules about offerings.

verses.text: Speak to Aaron and his sons and to all the people of Israel and say to them: When any one of the house of Israel or any of the foreigners in Israel offers his offering—be it for a vow or as a freewill offering that they present to the Lord for a burnt offering—
verses.comment: "Foreigners" is rendered as 'sojourner' in some translations; meaning is preserved.

verses.text: to be accepted, you shall offer a male without blemish from the cattle, the sheep, or the goats.
verses.comment: Maintains sacrificial qualifications explicitly.

verses.text: But whatsoever has a blemish, you shall not offer, for it will not be acceptable for you.
verses.comment: Phraseology matches the implication of Hebrew participle.

verses.text: And when anyone offers a sacrifice of peace offerings to the Lord to fulfill a vow or as a freewill offering from the herd or from the flock, it must be perfect to be accepted; there must be no blemish in it.
verses.comment: Restates the criteria for peace offerings.

verses.text: Animals that are blind, injured, maimed, have a running sore, scabs, or skin diseases, you shall not offer to the Lord or make any of these offerings by fire on the altar to the Lord.
verses.comment: Lists defects explicitly following Hebrew terms, avoiding euphemism.

verses.text: You may offer a bull or a lamb with a limb too long or too short as a freewill offering, but it will not be accepted as a vow offering.
verses.comment: Differentiates between types of offerings explicitly.

verses.text: You shall not offer to the Lord anything with bruised, crushed, torn, or cut testicles, nor shall you do this in your land.
verses.comment: 'Testicles' is rendered literally; upholding the requirement for wholeness.

verses.text: And from a foreigner you shall not offer as the food of your God any of these, because their blemish is in them. They will not be accepted for you.
verses.comment: Food of your God = offerings to God; follows Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Standard narrative introduction.

verses.text: When an ox, a sheep, or a goat is born, it shall remain with its mother for seven days, and from the eighth day on it shall be accepted as a food offering to the Lord.
verses.comment: Maintains Old Testament sacrificial timeframes.

verses.text: But you shall not slaughter an ox or a sheep and its young on the same day.
verses.comment: Commands compassion for animals; translates idiomatically and clearly.

verses.text: When you sacrifice a thanksgiving offering to the Lord, you shall sacrifice it so that you may be accepted.
verses.comment: Explicitly states the reason for correct procedure.

verses.text: It shall be eaten on the same day; you shall leave none of it until morning. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: Follows the Hebrew instruction literally.

verses.text: So you shall keep My commandments and do them. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: Reiterates obedience commandment; exact rendering.

verses.text: And you shall not profane My holy name, but I will be sanctified among the people of Israel. I am the Lord who sanctifies you,
verses.comment: 'Sanctified' means 'set apart as holy'; 'profane' is literal.

verses.text: who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord.
verses.comment: Concludes with the redemption formula found throughout Leviticus.
